input_args.examples: {'document_id': ['0003946', '0003952', '0001823', '0004973'], 'document_source': ['GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD', 'GARD'], 'document_url': ['https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3542/mental-retardation-x-linked-nonspecific', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/3545/merlob-grunebaum-reisner-syndrome', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/259/diabetes-insipidus-nephrogenic-mental-retardation-and-intracerebral-calcification', 'https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/gard/10708/pontocerebellar-hypoplasia-type-3'], 'category': [None, None, None, None], 'umls_cui': ['C1136249', 'C2931499', 'C0025362|C0687720|C0011848', 'C1842687|C0243069'], 'umls_semantic_types': ['T047', 'T047', 'T048|T047', 'T046|T047'], 'umls_semantic_group': ['Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders', 'Disorders'], 'synonyms': ['Mental retardation, X-linked nonspecific, type 1|Atkin Flaitz Patil Smith syndrome|Mental retardation, X-linked, 21|Mental retardation X-linked, Atkin type|MRX21', 'Familial opposable triphalangeal thumbs associated with duplication of the big toes', 'Schofer Beetz Bohl syndrome', 'Cerebellar atrophy with progressive microcephaly|CLAM|PCH with optic atrophy'], 'question_id': ['0003946-1', '0003952-1', '0001823-1', '0004973-1'], 'question_focus': ['Mental retardation, X-linked, nonspecific', 'Merlob Grunebaum Reisner syndrome', 'Diabetes insipidus nephrogenic mental retardation and intracerebral calcification', 'Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 3'], 'question_type': ['symptoms', 'symptoms', 'symptoms', 'symptoms'], 'question': ['What are the symptoms of Mental retardation, X-linked, nonspecific ?', 'What are the symptoms of Merlob Grunebaum Reisner syndrome ?', 'What are the symptoms of Diabetes insipidus nephrogenic mental retardation and intracerebral calcification ?', 'What are the symptoms of Pontocerebellar hypoplasia type 3 ?'], 'answer': ['What are the signs and symptoms of Mental retardation, X-linked, nonspecific? The Human Phenotype Ontology provides the following list of signs and symptoms for Mental retardation, X-linked, nonspecific. If the information is available, the table below includes how often the symptom is seen in people with this condition. You can use the MedlinePlus Medical Dictionary to look up the definitions for these medical terms. Signs and Symptoms Approximate number of patients (when available) Seizures 5% Autism - Dental crowding - Hyperactivity - Hypertelorism - Intellectual disability - Intellectual disability, moderate - Joint hypermobility - Mandibular prognathia - Open mouth - Short nose - Synophrys - Tented upper lip vermilion - Uplifted earlobe - Upslanted palpebral fissure - X-linked recessive inheritance - The Human Phenotype Ontology (HPO) has collected information on how often a sign or symptom occurs in a condition. Much of this information comes from Orphanet, a European rare disease database. The frequency of a sign or symptom is usually listed as a rough estimate of the percentage of patients who have that feature. The frequency may also be listed as a fraction. The first number of the fraction is how many people had the symptom, and the second number is the total number of people who were examined in one study. For example, a frequency of 25/25 means that in a study of 25 people all patients were found to have that symptom. Because these frequencies are based on a specific study, the fractions may be different if another group of patients are examined. Sometimes, no information on frequency is available. In these cases, the sign or symptom may be rare or common.', 'What are the signs and symptoms of Merlob Grunebaum Reisner syndrome? Much of this information comes from Orphanet, a European rare disease database. The frequency of a sign or symptom is usually listed as a rough estimate of the percentage of patients who have that feature. The frequency may also be listed as a fraction. The first number of the fraction is how many people had the symptom, and the second number is the total number of people who were examined in one study. For example, a frequency of 25/25 means that in a study of 25 people all patients were found to have that symptom. Because these frequencies are based on a specific study, the fractions may be different if another group of patients are examined. Sometimes, no information on frequency is available.
